questions.title: Gauss's Law - Electric Field
questions.question_text: Gauss's law for electricity states that the electric flux through any closed surface is proportional to the enclosed charge: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{E} = \frac{œÅ}{Œµ_0}$$ where E‚Éó is the electric field, œÅ is charge density, and Œµ‚ÇÄ = 8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤F/m. For a point charge Q = 10nC, find the electric field at distance r = 5cm.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Using $$E = \frac{1}{4œÄŒµ_0} \frac{Q}{r^2}$$ with Q = 10√ó10‚Åª‚ÅπC and r = 0.05m gives E = 3.6√ó10‚Å¥V/m

questions.title: Gauss's Law - Magnetic Field
questions.question_text: Gauss's law for magnetism states that magnetic field lines form closed loops with no magnetic monopoles: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ This can also be written in integral form as $$\oint \mathbf{B} \cdot d\mathbf{A} = 0$$ What does this imply about magnetic field lines?
choices: Magnetic field lines begin at north poles and end at south poles
Magnetic field lines are always closed loops with no beginning or end
The magnetic flux Œ¶B through any surface equals Œº‚ÇÄI
questions.correct_answer: Magnetic field lines are always closed loops with no beginning or end
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ means no magnetic monopoles exist - field lines must form closed loops
questions.feedback_incorrect: $$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$ is the mathematical statement that magnetic field lines have no sources or sinks

questions.title: Faraday's Law - Complex Notation
questions.question_text: Faraday's law describes electromagnetic induction: $$\nabla \times \mathbf{E} = -\frac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}$$ For a circular loop of radius r = 2cm in a time-varying magnetic field $$\mathbf{B}(t) = B_0 \cos(œât) \hat{z}$$ where B‚ÇÄ = 0.5T and œâ = 2œÄ√ó60rad/s, calculate the induced EMF magnitude |‚Ñ∞| = |dŒ¶B/dt|.
questions.feedback_correct: Excellent! $$Œ¶_B = B_0 œÄ r^2 \cos(œât)$$, so $$|‚Ñ∞| = \left|\frac{dŒ¶_B}{dt}\right| = B_0 œÄ r^2 œâ = 0.5 √ó œÄ √ó (0.02)^2 √ó 377 = 0.047\text{V}$$

questions.title: Amp√®re-Maxwell Law - Full Complexity
questions.question_text: The Amp√®re-Maxwell law (4th Maxwell equation) includes both conduction and displacement currents: $$\nabla \times \mathbf{B} = Œº_0 \mathbf{J} + Œº_0 Œµ_0 \frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$ The displacement current density is $$\mathbf{J}_D = Œµ_0 \frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$. For a parallel-plate capacitor with A = 1cm¬≤, d = 1mm, charging at dV/dt = 10‚Å∂V/s, find |JD|.
questions.feedback_correct: Perfect! $$E = V/d$$, so $$\frac{dE}{dt} = \frac{1}{d}\frac{dV}{dt}$$, giving $$|\mathbf{J}_D| = Œµ_0 \frac{10^6}{10^{-3}} = 8.854 \times 10^{-3}\text{ A/m¬≤}$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: For a parallel plate capacitor: $$\mathbf{E} = \frac{V}{d}\hat{z}$$, so $$\frac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t} = \frac{1}{d}\frac{dV}{dt}\hat{z}$$

questions.title: Maxwell Equations - Vector Identities
questions.question_text:
From Maxwell's equations in vacuum: $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{E} = 0$$, $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{B} = 0$$, $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{E} = - rac{\partial \mathbf{B}}{\partial t}$$, $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{B} = Œº_0 Œµ_0  rac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$. Taking the divergence of the 4th equation and using $$
abla \cdot (
abla 	imes \mathbf{B}) = 0$$, we can prove that $$ rac{\partial}{\partial t}(
abla \cdot \mathbf{E}) = 0$$, which is consistent with the 1st equation.
questions.feedback_correct:
True! Taking $$
abla \cdot$$ of $$
abla 	imes \mathbf{B} = Œº_0 Œµ_0  rac{\partial \mathbf{E}}{\partial t}$$ gives $$0 = Œº_0 Œµ_0  rac{\partial}{\partial t}(
abla \cdot \mathbf{E})$$, so $$
abla \cdot \mathbf{E}$$ is constant (and equals 0 in vacuum)
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the vector identity $$\nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{V}) = 0$$ for any vector field $$\mathbf{V}$$

questions.title: Wave Equation from Maxwell
questions.question_text: In vacuum, Maxwell's equations lead to the wave equation: $$\nabla^2 \mathbf{E} - Œº_0 Œµ_0 \frac{\partial^2 \mathbf{E}}{\partial t^2} = 0$$ The speed of electromagnetic waves is $$c = \frac{1}{\sqrt{Œº_0 Œµ_0}}$$. Given Œº‚ÇÄ = 4œÄ√ó10‚Åª‚Å∑H/m and Œµ‚ÇÄ = 8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤F/m, calculate c in m/s (√ó10‚Å∏).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Calculate $$\sqrt{Œº_0 Œµ_0} = \sqrt{4œÄ \times 10^{-7} \times 8.854 \times 10^{-12}}$$ first, then take reciprocal

questions.title: Boundary Conditions - Complex Subscripts
questions.question_text: At the boundary between two media, Maxwell's equations impose boundary conditions. For the tangential components: $$\mathbf{n} \times (\mathbf{E}_2 - \mathbf{E}_1) = 0$$ and $$\mathbf{n} \times (\mathbf{B}_2 - \mathbf{B}_1) = Œº_0 \mathbf{K}$$ where nÃÇ is the surface normal and K‚Éó is surface current density. For a perfect conductor (œÉ ‚Üí ‚àû), what are the boundary conditions?
choices: E‚Éó‚à• = 0, B‚Éó‚à• = Œº‚ÇÄK‚Éó at the surface
E‚Éó = 0 inside, B‚Éó‚ä• = Œº‚ÇÄœÉJ‚Éó at surface
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For perfect conductors: $$\mathbf{E}_{tangential} = 0$$ (no tangential E-field), $$\mathbf{B}_{tangential} = Œº_0 \mathbf{K}$$ (surface currents)
questions.feedback_incorrect: In perfect conductors: E‚Éó = 0 inside, so tangential E must be zero at surface. Surface currents create tangential B-field

questions.title: Poynting Vector - Energy Flow
questions.question_text: The Poynting vector describes electromagnetic energy flow: $$\mathbf{S} = \frac{1}{Œº_0} \mathbf{E} \times \mathbf{B}$$ For a plane wave $$\mathbf{E} = E_0 \cos(kz - œât) \hat{x}$$ and $$\mathbf{B} = \frac{E_0}{c} \cos(kz - œât) \hat{y}$$, the time-averaged intensity is $$\langle S \rangle = \frac{1}{2Œº_0 c} E_0^2$$. If E‚ÇÄ = 100V/m, find ‚ü®S‚ü© in W/m¬≤.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use $$\langle S \rangle = \frac{E_0^2}{2Œº_0 c}$$ where c = 3√ó10‚Å∏m/s and Œº‚ÇÄ = 4œÄ√ó10‚Åª‚Å∑H/m

questions.title: Stress Test - All Notation Types
questions.question_text: Maxwell stress tensor components in vacuum: $$T_{ij} = Œµ_0 \left(E_i E_j - \frac{1}{2}Œ¥_{ij} E^2\right) + \frac{1}{Œº_0}\left(B_i B_j - \frac{1}{2}Œ¥_{ij} B^2\right)$$ For uniform fields E‚Éó = E‚ÇÄ·∫ë and B‚Éó = B‚ÇÄxÃÇ, calculate T‚ÇÉ‚ÇÉ (the zz-component).
questions.feedback_correct: Excellent! Since E‚Éó = E‚ÇÄ·∫ë: E‚ÇÉ = E‚ÇÄ, E¬≤ = E‚ÇÄ¬≤. Since B‚Éó = B‚ÇÄxÃÇ: B‚ÇÉ = 0, B¬≤ = B‚ÇÄ¬≤. So $$T_{33} = Œµ_0(0 - E_0^2/2) + \frac{1}{Œº_0}(0 - B_0^2/2)$$
questions.feedback_incorrect: Substitute E‚ÇÉ = E‚ÇÄ, E¬≤ = E‚ÇÄ¬≤, B‚ÇÉ = 0, B¬≤ = B‚ÇÄ¬≤ into the tensor formula
